Cédric Beust ♔ wrote:
> On 11/28/05, Robert Watkins <yahoo@...> wrote:
>  >
>  > Another work around is to have another test that verifies the
>  > behaviour up to the point where the exception is expected. This
>  > wouldn't be expecting the exception, and so would presumably fail if
> 
> Which, if I'm not mistaken, would require...  dependent methods (being able
> to order the tests).

You are mistaken. :) It wouldn't require it; I don't mind if both tests 
fail for the same reason, although I might be concerned if 10 tests 
failed for the same reason. In the latter case, there's a design issue I 
need to work on.

>  > I personally don't like expecting exceptions in tests because I wish
>  > to verify the state of the exception, but each to their own...
> 
> It seems to be more an exception than a rule, but you can always stick to
> the try/catch approach if you really need that.
> 
> What "state" do you usually check on your exceptions?  Except for the
> message (which is probably not a good idea since you need to plan for
> internationalization), there is not much in that object, unless you make
> heavy use of your own exceptions (not a very common occurrence in my
> experience).

Indeed. I used to do that a lot, but now I don't. I think I found that 
all those custom exception classes weren't worth the effort.
